title: pets
text:
I love animals and am lucky to have a few in my life! Back home, my family has a beautiful Belgian Malinois-Shepherd mix named Sadie, and a very fluffy cat named Mittens. At my college house, my roommates and I have a cat named Bearâ€”heâ€™s incredibly comforting and always around when we need a little extra love.

title: Whatâ€™s Next?
text:
This next year is going to be full of exciting changes! Iâ€™m really looking forward to whatâ€™s ahead and have created an interactive map showing the places Iâ€™ll be traveling to in 2025 and 2026.
Right now, Iâ€™m in Santa Barbara for school. This summer (2025), Iâ€™ll be moving to Redlands, California for an internship at ESRI. Afterward, Iâ€™ll return to Santa Barbara for Fall Quarter, and in February 2026, Iâ€™ll head to the University of Queensland in Brisbane, Australia to finish my undergraduate education. Iâ€™ll come back to Santa Barbara for graduation, and then hope to spend the next summer job hunting and exploring in New York City â€” a place Iâ€™ve dreamed of living since I was little. It is going to be completely out of my comfort zone, but am going to push through this and live life to the fullest while I still can.

title: Geography 176C Project
text:
This project was completed for Geography 176C and explores nitrate contamination in Fresno County, California. Using GIS, I examined how proximity to almond and grape crops relates to groundwater contamination.

title: Hobbies
text: Some of my favorite things to do are explore the different hiking trails around Santa Barbara and go on runs. My favorite hikes include the Gaviota Wind Caves, Tangerine Falls, and the Montecito Hot Springs Trail. Living in Isla Vista makes it super convenient to run to the beach, and I often frequent the North Campus Open Space trail that leads to the bluffs at Ellwood. I try to run with friends whenever theyâ€™re aroundâ€”it makes it so much more fun, and a little competitive. Iâ€™m currently training for the Malibu Half Marathon in November, and I hope to run a full marathon in 2026!

title: Projects
text:
On this page, you will find a selection of my past coursework from geography and environmental studies classes, covering topics from GIS and environmental justice to fieldwork and data storytelling.

 

GEOG 176C â€“ Mapping Nitrate Contamination in Fresno County



This final project for Geography 176C is a spatial analysis of nitrate contamination in Fresno County domestic wells. This project applies kriging, spatial joins, and hot spot analysis to examine environmental justice concerns in relation to cropland proximity.





GEOG 176B â€“ Transportation Planning for the Olympics



This final project for my Geography 176B course focused on Los Angelesâ€™ transportation system, and if it is capable to handle the incoming population flux for the 2028 Olympics.



 

ES 40 â€“ Tidepooling Field Guide



An illustrated guide to tidepooling near UCSB, created for my ES 40 course. The guide highlights species identification and how to properly tidepool!

title: Kate Frankland
text: Hello! My name is Kate Frankland. and I am an Environmental Science student at UC Santa Barbara. I aim to pursue a career in corporate sustainability, contributing to developing solutions that will create positive environmental impacts while meeting business goals. I am interested in how technology and sustainable practices intersect and aim to further my skills in data analytics and geographic information systems (GIS).

title: Tidepooling Field Guide
text:

title: GEOG176B Final Project
text:
In this group project, we analyzed how Los Angelesâ€™ transportation systems are equipped to meet the demands of the upcoming Olympics, with a focus on current infrastructure capacity and the populations it is designed to serve.
